paragraphs.text:
%md
#Getting started with Spark

### In scope
* Share, try
* Install locally
* usefull tools
* reading/writing data

### Out of scope
* cluster settings
* streaming
* Dick Cheney's unknown's unknown


Most of the example are in scala, but things are simple enough that it should be understandable even if you do not have experience with it.

result.msg:
Getting started with Spark

In scope

  • Share, try
  • Install locally
  • usefull tools
  • reading/writing data

Out of scope

  • cluster settings
  • streaming
  • Dick Cheney's unknown's unknown

Most of the example are in scala, but things are simple enough that it should be understandable even if you do not have experience with it.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Local Installation
* Dowload pre-build http://spark.apache.org/downloads.html
* Choose newest here `(1.5.2) pre-build for hadoop 2.6 and later` but I tried 1.6 over the weekend
* Untar wherever you like (I did `$HOME/local_spark/`)
* [path-to-spark]  `./bin/spark-shell`
    * `--master` to set the master
        * `local` locally,  one worker thread
        * `local[n]` locally, `n` worker thread (`n= * ` mean # of core available)
        *  `[HOST]PORT:` 
        *  ...
* http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/
    1. e.g.

result.msg:
Local Installation

  • Dowload pre-build http://spark.apache.org/downloads.html
  • Choose newest here (1.5.2) pre-build for hadoop 2.6 and later but I tried 1.6 over the weekend
  • Untar wherever you like (I did $HOME/local_spark/)
  • [path-to-spark] ./bin/spark-shell
    • --master to set the master
      • local locally, one worker thread
      • local[n] locally, n worker thread (n= * mean # of core available)
      • [HOST]PORT:
      • …
  • http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/
    1. e.g.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Shell
* **scala** `./bin/spark-shell` (a modified version of the Scala shell)
* **pyspark** `./bin/pyspark`
    * To include in python interpreter, set these variables
    ```
    export PYTHONPATH=$SPARK_HOME/python:$SPARK_HOME/python/build:$PYTHONPATH
    export PYTHONPATH=$SPARK_HOME/python/lib/py4j-0.8.2.1-src.zip:$PYTHONPATH
    ```

result.msg:
Shell

  • scala ./bin/spark-shell (a modified version of the Scala shell)
  • pyspark ./bin/pyspark
    • To include in python interpreter, set these variables
      export PYTHONPATH=$SPARK_HOME/python:$SPARK_HOME/python/build:$PYTHONPATH
export PYTHONPATH=$SPARK_HOME/python/lib/py4j-0.8.2.1-src.zip:$PYTHONPATH

### Spark Context
Your connection to the spark cluster.  Allows to
* Run jobs
* Accessing service s.a.  Task scheduler
* Creating RDDs
* ...

%md
## Notebooks
Well known from Jupyter user (formerly known as ipython notebook)
* **Zeppelin** used here
    * built on JVM
    * Spark first
    * Apache incubator
* **Jupyter** (not tried)
    * Very mature
    * huge community
* **Databricks**
    * Great
    * Commercial $$$
* **More**
    * [Beaker notebook](http://beakernotebook.com/)
    * [spark-notebook](https://github.com/andypetrella/spark-notebook/)
    * ...

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Zeppelin
easy install
* download `git clone https://github.com/apache/incubator-zeppelin/`
* `cd incubator-zeppelin/`
* `mvn clean package -Pspark-1.5 -DskipTests`
* `./bin/zeppelin-daemon.sh start`
* go to `http://localhost:8080/`

result.msg:
Zeppelin

easy install

  • download git clone https://github.com/apache/incubator-zeppelin/
  • cd incubator-zeppelin/
  • mvn clean package -Pspark-1.5 -DskipTests
  • ./bin/zeppelin-daemon.sh start
  • go to http://localhost:8080/

paragraphs.text:
%md
##RDD
Resillient Distributed Datasets are the basic abstractions in Spark.
They are immutable and distributed (partionned) over the available cluster.
Calculation can be performed in parallel over the partitionned elements.

result.msg:
RDD

Resillient Distributed Datasets are the basic abstractions in Spark.
They are immutable and distributed (partionned) over the available cluster.
Calculation can be performed in parallel over the partitionned elements.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Reading data
Spark SQL provides inbuilt support for 3 types of data sources:
* Parquet (default)
* Json
* Jdbc

example:
`val people = sqlContext.read.json("people.json")`


**Warning**: from spark docs (about json):
Each line must contain a separate, self-contained valid JSON object. As a consequence, a regular multi-line JSON file will most often fail.

### The cheating's way
use non-spark tool, like pandas to read the data and turn it into a spark-native format.
Caveat: limited by memory

result.msg:
Reading data

Spark SQL provides inbuilt support for 3 types of data sources:

  • Parquet (default)
  • Json
  • Jdbc

example:
val people = sqlContext.read.json("people.json")

Warning: from spark docs (about json):
Each line must contain a separate, self-contained valid JSON object. As a consequence, a regular multi-line JSON file will most often fail.

The cheating's way

use non-spark tool, like pandas to read the data and turn it into a spark-native format.
Caveat: limited by memory

%md
##csv
###Brute force: using case class
By looking at the rows, define a case classe where you infer the type.  In case of doubt, use `String`
We can take any subsample of the fields.

result.msg:
csv

Brute force: using case class

By looking at the rows, define a case classe where you infer the type. In case of doubt, use String
We can take any subsample of the fields.

paragraphs.text: case class Listing(id: Integer,name: String, neighbourhood: String, latitude: Double, longitude: Double)

result.msg: defined class Listing

paragraphs.text:
val listings = linesRDD.map(s => s.split(",")).filter(s => s(0) != "id").map(
    s => Listing(s(0).toInt,
            s(1),
            s(5),
            s(6).toFloat,
            s(7).toFloat
        )
)

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Automize access csv-to-rdd fields
If you want to ease the access the the elements

result.msg:
Automize access csv-to-rdd fields

If you want to ease the access the the elements

paragraphs.text:
//reading the csv
val headersAndRows = linesRDD.map(line => line.split(",").map(_.trim))
val header = headersAndRows.first
val data = headersAndRows.filter(_(0) != header(0))
val maps = data.map(splits => header.zip(splits).toMap)

%md
### Spark packages
Community contribution to spark [here](http://spark-packages.org/)

#### example [spark-csv](https://github.com/databricks/spark-csv)
From the shell
`$SPARK_HOME/bin/spark-shell --packages com.databricks:spark-csv_2.10:1.3.0`
**Note**: If inside Zeppelin notebook (see first cell of this notebook)

result.msg:
Spark packages

Community contribution to spark here

example spark-csv

From the shell
$SPARK_HOME/bin/spark-shell --packages com.databricks:spark-csv_2.10:1.3.0
Note: Inside Zeppelin notebook (see first cell of this notebook)

paragraphs.text:
val df = sqlContext.read
    .format("com.databricks.spark.csv")
    .option("header", "true") // Use first line of all files as header
    .option("inferSchema", "true") // Automatically infer data types //.option("quote", "\"")
    .option("mode", "DROPMALFORMED")
    .load("data/airbnb/mtl_listings.csv")

paragraphs.text:
%md
##DataFrames
* Introduced in spark 1.3
* Build on RDD
* "Prefered abstraction in Spark"
    * Simpler
    * Better optimized (especially for python, R... any non-scala/jave)
* Inspired by R and Pandas dataframe **but immutable**

###Creation
* by parallelizing existing collections (e.g. RDDs, Pandas DataFrames)
* by transforming and existing DataFrame
* from files in storage system (e.g. parquet files)

result.msg:
DataFrames

  • Introduced in spark 1.3
  • Build on RDD
  • “Prefered abstraction in Spark”
    • Simpler
    • Better optimized (especially for python, R… any non-scala/jave)
  • Inspired by R and Pandas dataframe but immutable

Creation

  • by parallelizing existing collections (e.g. RDDs, Pandas DataFrames)
  • by transforming and existing DataFrame
  • from files in storage system (e.g. parquet files)

%md
## Spark SQL
* SQLContext (default) support a “rich subset dialect of SQL 92”
* HiveContext "dialect is hiveql" richer than SQLContext

result.msg:
Spark SQL

  • SQLContext (default) support a “rich subset dialect of SQL 92”
  • HiveContext “dialect is hiveql” richer than SQLContext

paragraphs.text:
%md
Let's create a table by registering the dataframe
* Same performance as DataFrames
* Better performance as RDDs

result.msg:
Let's create a table by registering the dataframe

  • Same performance as DataFrames
  • Better performance as RDDs

paragraphs.text: df.registerTempTable("airbnb")

sqlContext.sql(
    """
        SELECT name, price
        FROM airbnb
        LIMIT 5
    """
).show

%md
Or in zeppelin just make the cell sql

result.msg: Or in zeppelin just make the cell sql

paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT AVG(reviews_per_month) monthly_reviews, neighbourhood
FROM airbnb
GROUP BY neighbourhood
ORDER BY monthly_reviews DESC
LIMIT 8
